title: Medicine in the Age of Electronic Health Records

author: Nigam H. Shah, School of Medicine, Stanford University

segmentation: I'm going to try to talk to you about medicine in the age of electronic Health records.
And I have very little text on my slides.
It's mostly pictures and so depending on your reaction I can keep changing the story.
That's the whole point of having it that way.
But before we start, I want to do a quick audience poll.
What fraction of unstructured fraction of useful data in medicine do you think is unstructured?
Just pick a number between zero and 100.
90 OK, so the very optimistic audience.
Usually I get responses between 50 to 9095.
If you know someone just wants to mess with me, most people would agree that between 80 to 90% of data is unstructured.

So the way all of this started was in 2010 when I got on the faculty 2011 when I got on the faculty at Stanford, I ask myself the question if features are going to get adopted so widely as presumed, and if 8090% of the data is unstructured.
What should a Doctor Who knows a little bit of programming do?
And so the answer to that was to look at the unstructured data and then try to do new things in medicine.
So the most of the focus is on learning something about the disease, the underlying medical condition rather than coming up with fancy algorithm.
Some of the exciting results we've had, which I'll show you today use nothing more than odds ratios.
Simple division.
OK, so.
The other key point I want to hit home is that there's a difference between medicine and healthcare.
Big data or data mining?
Or, you know, put your favorite buzzword.
There has a role in both the science of medicine.
And the practice of medicine, and it's really important to make this distinction clear for yourself.
As you do projects as you develop new procedures, new new algorithms.

Because if you confuse these two, what will happen is that you're thinking you're advancing the practice, but you end up advancing the science, and you get very little traction with the hospitals, and I'll give very concrete examples.
Two or three of them during the talk.
The second key point is that the priorities are different for the science and the practice.
And this one I won't talk about it right now.
I'll come back to it during the during the specific examples.
And of course there is.
There are activities at the junction of these to the science in the practice where you can get the most bang for your Buck, so to speak.
You can get the most impact of what you do.
OK, so.
Things in my group revolve around data of multiple types, adverse event reports, clinical trials, chemical databases, health forums, web search logs, physician search logs.
There's a we were lucky to get access to two years worth of search logs for the whole US on uptodate.com, which is a one of the leading physician search engine's that's used.
And you already heard from Eric Horvitz about some of the work on the Internet query logs.
Most of this conversation is going to focus around medical records.
And I want to plant this image into your head, which I call the patient feature matrix.
So the rows are patients or people.
The columns are features.
Drugs, diseases, procedures, devices.
The list of features in medicine, though large, is finite.
Yes, there's lots of drugs, but there's only 4900 or so of them that are FDA approved diseases.
Yes, there's there's lots of them, but about 15,000 of them will capture most of the case volume that you see, and you could have multiple semantic groups among them.
So for this conversation, let's just have drugs, diseases, procedures, and devices.
So columns are these features.
Rows are people and then we have the time axis.
And then typically your data matrices will have presence or absence or will have a number and so on.
But in medicine there's one little sort of footnote, which is that you also have negation.
You have explicit assertions that say no hypertension, no dyspnea.

And that's a key difference from the typical large datasets that you would get where a user either did something or didn't do it, or you don't know, but nobody says they saw this thing and chose not to do something, so there's that.
Explicit negation part is missing, so that's why we have three values, one for present, 0 for absence.
And let's say we have a -- 1 for recording this additional thing about negation.
OK.
So with that context.
If you had.
Data from a million patients or 6 million patients, or 10,000,000 patients.
So you have lots of rows.
You have about 50,000 columns, so statistics works nicely.
You have more samples than you have features, and you have 10 to 15 years of data.
What can you do with it?
And that's sort of the bulk of the conversation today.
So the problem?
The first problem that I'm going to talk about is that about 96% of medical care is best guesses.
And this might come as a surprise, but randomized clinical trials typically focus on doing one thing, which is testing if the intervention that they're testing is better than water or doing nothing.
And when when a typical patient comes in the door, very rarely does the evidence from a randomized clinical trial apply directly.
So there is no so-called textbook case, and that's the reason clinical trials have a lot of trouble recruiting.
Even in a well studied feel like cardiology, about 19% of the recommendations from the American Heart Association are based on Arctic grade evidence.
19% and that Cineville studied field.
And if you ask a practicing physician, what fraction of the times does a does a guideline apply to the case to the patient they have in front of them?
You get responses anywhere between 10 to 20%.
So multiply those two.
There's your 4%, and so 96% of the time you're taking your best guess based on what have you seen before.
So then the opportunity is to make decisions based on what happened to real people like the patient in front of you.
'cause that is what doctors do.
They tried when faced with a situation that there's no existing RCT based guideline.
What you try to do is ask the question how many other people have I seen?
An or my colleagues have seen and what did they choose to do and what happened?
The solution therefore I propose, is that we find similar patients using all the data that we have at our hand and then try to see trajectories of similar patient, ideally at the bedside.
We're not there yet at the bedside, but getting closer.
And the main issues, of course, are that getting the data and access and the amount are sort of the two main risks you have to overcome.
So this idea of using aggregate patient data at the bedside.
We propose a solution which we call the green button.
So what do I mean by that?
So let's say you have a patient coming in.
If there's a guideline available, by all means use that.
If not, press this thing that I haven't shown you yet called the green button, and if the green button works, you get a large cohort of similar people, gets you some practice based evidence.
Otherwise you can keep doing what you were doing.
But as a side effect, it collects.
How often does this question get asked?
That allows you to prioritize?
Should I do a clinical trial?
How much?
How much resources should I allocate to it?
And so on.
So we wrote this as a model for policy around evidence use in medicine.
So if you were to press this green button, the description of your patient.
Unstructured would get passed to a analysis engine with the desired outcome and you may or may not have an intervention.
You might say in this case, which antihypertensive would get me to this outcome.
Or you might leave it blank and ask what would lead me to that outcome and then the result you would get is some time to event.

So in this case blood pressure coming down to your desired level, what was strongly associated with that outcome and then your confidence in the cohort based on which you're doing this 'cause if you don't know what's the underlying data, you don't know how much they trust.
The associations that you see.
So this is great.
This these two things are sort of in the appendices of this paper and Health Affairs.
It's a policy piece, and then I'll walk you through the different pieces.
We don't have an integrated system yet at Stanford, but we would like to build one someday so.
That's the first piece answering clinical questions.
So let's start with an example from 2010.
This was before I joined as a faculty there.
So these people, Jennifer Frankovich, Chris Longhurst, and Scott Sutherland were faced with having to treat a 13 year old female with systemic lupus erythematous.
It's a disease that typically affects middle aged women.
And.
There's nothing in the textbooks how to treat such an individual.
They convened, just Jennifer convened a panel of experts, got very conflicting opinions, and then she did something very shocking.
Not shocking to computer scientists and data mining people, but she queried our data warehouse.
So the hospital had seen 98 people with this particular condition.
No individual doctor had, but the hospital had and the problem they were worried about thrombosis.
These are the actual words they're searching for, thrombus, thrombosis, and blood clot.
And as you can see, there's not much string similarity between blood clot and thrombus, so you need to know from somewhere outside that these two things mean the same thing.
And 10 out of these 98 people had this problem.
And then they started creating for the different risk factors, which would give them some indication into what to do for this patient.
So proteinuria, these are the words used, pancreatitis.
Here are the words used anti phospholipid antibodies.
She's searching for aspirin.
So again, you need to know that aspirin is given to kids if and only if they are positive for this lab test and so you can have these surrogate variables.
And then doing some counting, getting some risk ratios and then in this particular case, choosing choosing to use thrombolytic therapy because this particular patient had proteinuria for a long time.
So this got them into all sorts of trouble.
So I'm not going to talk about the trouble they had, but when they.
I heard about this work.
Groups went backwards.
I see variables.
I see terms and concepts.
I see some counts an I see some risk calculations.
And I was told that Stanford has a data warehouse and these green wiggly lines are show how much data has accumulated overtime.
And so if I'm able to generate this patient feature matrix that I talked to you about.
I can then identify my terms and concepts as the features.
I can group them into my variables of interest.
I can do the counting and then ask a new question.
So that's what we did.
We built a system, a system in the sense that it's an academic kludge, some Python scripts, some Java, a little bit of R, lots of walking around shell scripting and coffee runs.
But at the end of the day, we were able to do a new study.
So kids were juvenile, idiopathic arthritis are at risk for uveitis, and there is 4 known risk factors which are up there, which we reproduce just for sanity purposes.
So if your uveitis starts in less than four joints, or you're positive for these two laptops A and a antinuclear antibodies or RF factor, one of them is protective, and psoriasis increases your risk.
So we were able to reproduce four things that we already knew.
One of the parents of the one of the patients with this condition had a hypothesis that allergies.
Predispose to uveitis.
And we use allergies and allergy medications as a surrogate, and we tested that Association.
And yes, we see an increased risk.
So this is what leads us to this fork between the practice and the signs.
If I want to pursue the science, then I have to figure out how is it that allergies predispose to uveitis?
What is the underlying immune mechanism?
What can I do to block it or drugs?
Might I use and so on?
But if I want to go the practice route.
Do you have allergies or not?
Is a question that is asked every time at a doctor visit.
I'm sure if you've been to a doctor, you filled out a form that says do you have allergies and are you taking allergy meds?
Same thing with the kids.
We can use that to prioritize which child gets eye exams first, 'cause typically you're supposed to go every six months.
With these patients, you go once you go twice, life happens, and then nobody shows up again.
And so if you're able to prioritize and use calendaring, given this Association, you can prevent a kid from going black.
So very simple data mining.
We're looking at odds ratios and associations through lots of unstructured data.

So the student who did this came up with this acronym called clinical event Recognizer.
Clever and I thought that was a pretty clever acronym.
So the idea is to go through this unstructured data and instead of doing full NLP, we look we do dictionary based vlookups.
So what we'll do is for a sentence like this will put it into a structure.
Let's just think of it as a matrix for now.
That's not exactly how we store it, but for the patient, which is a row and a term.
I want to know if that particular term is mentioned.
And if it's mentioned is it negated?
So in this case acute fractures is negated.
So we put a -- 1 over there.
Then we do that overtime for 3 million terms in about 2 million patients.

At this point, I don't disambiguate that if you see stroke SDR OK, is it heat stroke, heart stroke, cerebral vascular stroke, or what have you that is deferred as much as possible later in the analysis because the advantage of doing that is that if at the end of the day when I'm trying to disambiguate an icy stroke, and I see age under 18 and I see ice packs, then it's a much easier problem to disambiguate and say it's heat stroke rather than trying to figure it out up front.
So we defer that binding when you give me a question.
Say juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
We go to these things called medical ontologies.
Some of you might have heard of ICD 9 Sno Med or NCI Thesaurus.
The problem is, there's too many of them.
So for your favorite disease, let's say this green box.
There will be one node in multiple directed acyclic graphs.
So we figured out a way to sort of find equivalence classes.

Bunch of them altogether, pick up the different variants of those names from all of them, and then have this bag of words that is surrounded by the red circle in order to stand in for a particular concept, and then the second thing we do is use the hierarchy part of it.
Acetaminophen, for example, has 1800 trade names.
If you're processing unstructured text, then you're making features out of it.
I mean, you don't have to come to KDD to figure out that one feature is better than 1800.
And so the hierarchies definitely help in reducing the complexity of your data.
And then the last piece is counting keeping track of the negation, keeping track of what was said where in the document.
Is it history?
Is it family history?
And that allows us to create this patient feature matrix that I was talking about.
So just to make it very concrete, the second step when done for this arthritis example, it expands into the soandso ICD 9 codes.
Here the words allergy medications expand into all of this.
The different trade names and so on, and that all of that happens behind the scenes.
You just tell me juvenile arthritis and then these expansions happen for you.

No, peripheral artery disease is a condition which is increasing very rapidly both here and in the developing countries, and we don't fully understand why.

People with better for larger disease also have some degree of heart failure.

We do see that the rate at which claudication changes to no claudication is threefold higher in the people who got the drug.
So, we see the efficacy of the drug but don't see the side effect.

No increase in cardiovascular events.
We went to hospital across the street.
Found 97 people with peripheral artery disease.
Heart failure getting this drug.
No increase in any of the bad stuff.

So it's probably premature to conclude that the drug is safe.
